column8:
Intervenção do Primeiro-Ministro no debate quinzenal na Assembleia da República sobre Política Social

Senhor Presidente

Senhoras e Senhores Deputados

De entre as questões sociais que se colocam ao nosso País a questão do desemprego é sem dúvida a que mais preocupa os portugueses.

E, no desemprego, uma das áreas mais criticas é aquela que tem a ver com a inserção de jovens na vida activa. Não apenas pela dificuldade de emprego mas igualmente pelos percursos longos e instáveis que os jovens percorrem até atingirem situações profissionais mais estáveis.

Mas enfrentar o problema das dificuldades de inserção dos jovens no mercado de trabalho implica, antes de mais, conhecê-lo.

O desemprego dos jovens aumentou em todos os países porque os jovens são os primeiros a sofrer quando há uma contracção abrupta e profunda do mercado de trabalho, dado que não têm nem experiência profissional nem ligações ao mundo do trabalho.

Mas que não haja nenhum equívoco: a qualificação continua a ser o factor determinante para o acesso ao emprego. Os dados do INE são deste ponto de vista esclarecedores. No quarto trimestre de 2010 aumentou o emprego nos jovens com ensino superior. Mais 34,9 mil pessoas licenciadas obtiveram emprego. Inversamente diminuiu o emprego naqueles que têm o nono ano ou menos.

Por outro lado, o desemprego dos licenciados aumentou 4,2%, enquanto que nos que têm o nono ano ou menos o aumento foi de 28,9%.

Estes números provam que as qualificações protegem os trabalhadores do desemprego, e que as políticas públicas de formação de capital humano são a estratégia certa para garantir mais oportunidades aos jovens.

Por isso o Governo não alinha em discursos que instrumentalizam os descontentamentos cristalizando uma ideia falsa e perigosa – a de que a educação não promove a empregabilidade. Pelo contrário: aprender mais e estudar mais compensa e aumenta as oportunidades de emprego para os jovens. É por isso que o investimento em educação em todos os níveis – básico, secundário e superior – é o contributo mais importante que a sociedade pode dar para promover a inserção dos jovens no mercado de trabalho.

É claro que só o regresso do crescimento económico permitirá aumentar sustentadamente a inserção dos jovens no mercado de trabalho e tirar partido do seu elevado nível de qualificações e competências e da sua capacidade de inovação.

Mas que fique bem claro, a nossa opção está feita. Portugal escolheu um caminho que é o caminho de mais educação, de mais qualificações, de mais ciência, inovação e tecnologia.

Foi para isso que fizemos crescer a percentagem de jovens no ensino superior para níveis idênticos aos da UE.

Foi para isso que fizemos crescer a percentagem de investigadores na população activa para acima da média da União Europeia.

É para isso que estamos a reduzir de forma decisiva o abandono e o insucesso escolar.

Porque é esse o caminho que garante uma economia competitiva, empresas mais qualificadas, melhores empregos e rendimentos mais elevados. E desse caminho não nos podemos afastar.

Uma economia que quer ter sucesso nos mercados mais competitivos não pode dispensar o seu recurso fundamental – uma população qualificada.

O papel do Estado, no âmbito de uma estratégia de políticas activas de emprego, deve ser o de criar oportunidades aos jovens para estabelecerem uma ligação durável e qualificada ao mercado de trabalho. Num contexto exigente para todos os agentes económicos, o Estado deve ser capaz de criar mecanismos que melhorem:

Entre o caminho seguido por aqueles que instrumentalizam o problema da inserção profissional dos jovens para tudo criticar e nada propor, e o caminho daqueles que consideram que o problema se resolve com a radical fragilização dos percursos profissionais, o Governo reforça a sua estratégia de políticas activas de emprego ajustadas a um contexto económico particularmente adverso. 

Senhor Presidente

Senhoras e Senhores Deputados

É nesta linha que o Governo está comprometido: com propostas concretas e com objectivos quantificados e verificáveis. É por isso que gostaria de apresentar ao Parlamento cinco medidas que o Governo vai tomar orientadas para a promoção da inserção dos jovens no mercado de trabalho.

Primeira medida: aumento para 50 000 do número de estágios profissionais.

No conjunto de políticas activas de emprego os estágios profissionais remunerados são das mais bem sucedidas, já que o nível de contratação que geram ronda os 70%. Assim o Governo decidiu ampliar esta medida passando de uma realização de 37 000 em 2010 para 50 000 em 2011. Esta medida integra um duplo efeito positivo: constitui uma poderosa via de acesso ao mercado de trabalho mas, ao mesmo tempo, pode ser um importante contributo para a qualificação das empresas, especialmente as PMEs.

Segunda medida: integração dos estagiários na segurança social.

Esta é uma medida inovadora de inegável justiça e com vários impactos positivos.

Desde logo, garante que a carreira contributiva dos jovens se inicia mais cedo, assegurando-lhes direitos imediatos e diferidos - ou seja a protecção na doença, maternidade e desemprego, bem como a formação de direitos em matéria de pensões. Por outro lado, a integração na Segurança Social reforça o carácter profissionalizante desta relação de trabalho. É também assim que se contraria a excessiva segmentação do mercado de trabalho.

Terceira medida: interdição dos estágios profissionais não remunerados.

Esta é uma medida essencial para combater uma prática socialmente inaceitável de obtenção de trabalho não pago e de frustração das expectativas dos jovens, para além de prefigurar situações de concorrência desleal. Esta medida não abrangerá estágios de muito curta duração ou de natureza curricular

Quarta medida: lançamento de um programa de requalificação de jovens licenciados de baixa empregabilidade.

Trata-se associar serviços públicos de emprego, instituições de ensino superior (Universidades e Politécnicos) e empresas para propiciar a jovens nesta situação oportunidades de formação de natureza complementar mais adequada às necessidades do mercado de trabalho. Na primeira fase este programa tem como objectivo envolver 5000 jovens com formação superior e em situação de desemprego.

Quinta medida: reforçar as medidas de qualificação das empresas exportadoras promovendo a integração de jovens quadros através do programa Inov-Export.

Este programa de indiscutível mérito para a modernização empresarial verá reforçada a sua prioridade através do envolvimento das associações empresariais. O programa Inov-Export passará a ser gerido em parceria com as associações dos sectores exportadores e deverá envolver cerca de 500 jovens em 2011.

Senhor Presidente

Senhoras e Senhores Deputados

Está bem claro qual a prioridade actual da política económica para Portugal: pôr as contas públicas em ordem. É isso que estamos a fazer. Por um lado, garantimos os objectivos da execução orçamental de 2010. Por outro lado, em de Janeiro de 2011 o défice orçamental da Administração Central reduziu-se em 58,6% quando comparado com o mês homólogo.

Falta ainda um longo caminho a percorrer para garantirmos a execução plena do objectivo orçamental. Mas este é, indiscutivelmente, um bom começo.

No entanto, a prioridade que elegemos como fundamental, não nos afasta do objectivo da modernização da nossa economia e da nossa sociedade. Da criação de mais oportunidades para todos. E, em particular, da criação de mais oportunidades para os jovens.

Estes não são objectivos contraditórios. Estes são os objectivos certos. Os objectivos certos para, hoje, defender Portugal.

column1: Debate quinzenal: novas medidas para a competitividade e modernização da economia
column6: Prime Minister's intervention in the debate Biweekly in parliament on economic policy Mr. President Ladies and gentlemen1. Good results in the implementation of NSRFPortugal has today ahead objectives of great importance for the present and for the future.And it is true that the most immediate priority is to ensure strict budgetary implementation for strengthening confidence in our economy and ensure the conditions for their external financing, the fact remains that we have to learn to associate the consolidation of public accounts to strengthening competitiveness and modernization of our economy - an essential condition for more growth and more jobs.For this, the proper implementation of the National Strategic Reference Framework is an absolutely fundamental objective of the country. I will therefore give account to Parliament of a fact of utmost importance: Portugal reached in 2010, 23% of overall implementation of the Community NSRF funds, thus exceeding the target of 20% that had been fixed at the beginning of the year. These results place Portugal as one of the most advanced European countries in the implementation of EU funds. no setThe implementation of Community funds, during the year 2010 exceeded 3250 million, leveraging a total investment of more than 5000 million, corresponding to more than 3% of GDP. In fact, in one year, duplicámos the funds run by the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund and triplicámos funds performed the ERDF [European Regional Development Fund].To get an idea of ​​what it is, I just note the following: the results made 2010 the best year ever in the absorption of EU fundsWith all that this means to stimulate the economy, support employment and contribute to the structural modernization of our manufacturing sector. Mr. President Ladies and gentlemenThe conclusion is clear: Portugal is running well Community NSRF funds and this is to be a powerful tool to support the promotion and modernization of our economy.With this effort, Portugal met, in 2010, in most operational programs, the goals the EU has set the end of 2011, which belies those who, in his usual catasfrofista style, predicting the loss of Community funds. The truth is different: cheated again!And these results in the implementation of the NSRF are having a very concrete translation in our economy and in the lives of the Portuguese. They are over600 schoolsthat they are completed or under construction. It is over4000 companies are being supported to invest and export. They are over800000 Portuguese covered by trainingTo improve their skills and qualifications. Are thedozens of laboratories and scientific research institutions and more than 7,500 fellowsin advanced training. Finally are the81 cities with urban regeneration initiatives. E Also in Proder [Rural Development Programme]much we improved the implementation rate. Public support for investment in agriculture in this context amounted to EUR 580 million in 2010 alone, while payments under the income support amounted to EUR 840 million. Thus, the implementation rate of the Proder investment now stands at 28.1%.Mr. President,  Ladies and gentlemenI want to point out, and do it with taste, the proper implementation of NSRF funds resulted from the response and effort of all stakeholders - business, management and authorities. But it was also the result of direct response measures to the effects of the crisis and easing the implementation of the funds, such as the qualification-employment program; the creation of credit lines for SMEs; the selective increase in the rates of co-financing; the creation of permanent counter; increased funding of school facilities; simplification of procedures and the proper acceleration of payments.But allow me to highlight the scale of business investment. The result of the recovery in exports, we now have more than 4700 projects underway, an eligible investment of 6638 million. This week completed a new phase contests, directed exclusively to exporting companies, having registered the highest demand ever: 1091 projects, for a total investment of 2078 million, broken down by productive innovation projects, creation companies and international promotional activities, all presented by export companies. This is surely one of the biggest and best signal response of companies and our export sector, the challenges of the country. A mobilization response effort. A reliable answer.2. New ambitious goals for 2011Mr. President Ladies and gentlemenThe results achieved in 2010 and the requirements of our economy have led the government to set for 2011 an even more ambitious goal: to achieve 40% of overall implementation of the NSRF funds. This objective corresponds to a further acceleration in the pace of implementation of the funds and the strengthening of key strategic options of the NSRF: qualification of human resources; innovation and internationalization of the economy; recovery and competitiveness of the territory.In the same way, the Proder Investment performance target for 2011 was set at 42%, Which means another strong reinforcement of support for Portuguese agriculture.3. An agenda for the modernizationMr. President  Ladies and gentlemenThe acceleration of the implementation of the NSRF assumes an agenda for competitiveness and modernization of the Portuguese economy. And I would like to present you here some of the concrete measures that will allow us to achieve the ambitious target set for 2011.1 - We will increase by 50%, ie, more than 140 million euros, the allocation to contests now concluded under the Incentive Scheme for exporting companies. We create so conditions for the essential: to support more businesses, more projects, the most important time for our economy.2 - We will strengthen the credit line NSRF Invest, which currently stands at 850 million euros to support companies in financing the national contribution required for the project implementation;3 - will increase to 75% the maximum rate of support for eligible business investment, in order to remedy the difficulties of access to bank financing;4 - We will open in 2011, new tenders under the incentive schemes, with a budget of 780 million euros, of which it is estimated that around EUR 560 million are absorbed by exporters;5 - will release also in 2011 specifically directed to innovative sectors competitions, such as the electrical mobility;6 - We will ensure, as in the 1st quarter of 2011, the availability of the EIB Framework Loan in the amount of 1 500 million euros, to support the national public counterpart of NSRF projects;7 th - Finally, we will renew and reinforce the incentives to local government investment in three key areas: school centers, water and sanitation, and urban regeneration.4. A national taskMr. President,  Ladies and gentlemenThis is a time that demands the best of ourselves to face a difficult situation that the international crisis has created.The Government is determined to continue to do their part to overcome the difficulties. With courage, with work and ambition. This is how to defend the country. This is the attitude of one who does not give up or turn to face the problems.But I know we can count on the Portuguese. With your effort and your initiative. Why is the Portuguese who we put our trust. And it is because we trust in the Portuguese, who trust in the future of Portugal.

Intervenção do Primeiro-Ministro no Debate Quinzenal na Assembleia da República sobre política económica

Senhor Presidente

Senhoras e Senhores Deputados

1. Bons resultados na execução do QREN

Portugal tem hoje pela frente objectivos de enorme importância para o presente e para o futuro.

E se é verdade que a prioridade mais imediata é garantir uma rigorosa execução orçamental que permita reforçar a confiança na nossa economia e assegurar as condições para o seu financiamento externo, não é menos verdade que temos de saber associar a consolidação das contas públicas ao reforço da competitividade e da modernização da nossa economia - condição essencial para mais crescimento e mais emprego.

Para isso, a boa execução do Quadro de Referência Estratégico Nacional constitui um objectivo absolutamente fundamental do País.

Quero, pois, dar conta à Assembleia da República de um dado da maior importância:

Portugal atingiu, em 2010, 23% de execução global dos fundos comunitários do QREN, superando assim a meta de 20% que tinha sido fixada no início do ano

.

Estes resultados colocam Portugal como um dos países europeus mais adiantados na execução dos fundos comunitários.

No conjunto

, a execução de fundos comunitários, ao longo do ano de 2010, superou os 3 250 milhões de euros, alavancando um investimento total superior a 5 000 milhões de euros, o que corresponde a mais de 3% do PIB

.

De facto, num só ano,

duplicámos

as verbas executadas do Fundo Social Europeu e do Fundo de Coesão e

triplicámos

as verbas executadas do Feder [Fundo Europeu de Desenvolvimento Regional].

Para se ter uma ideia do que isto representa, faço notar apenas o seguinte:

os resultados obtidos fizeram de 2010 o melhor ano de sempre na absorção de fundos comunitários

, com tudo o que isto significa de estímulo à economia, de apoio ao emprego e de contributo para a modernização estrutural do nosso sector produtivo.

Senhor Presidente

Senhoras e Senhores Deputados

A conclusão é clara:

Portugal está a executar bem os fundos comunitários do QREN

e este facto está a constituir um poderoso instrumento de apoio à dinamização e à modernização da nossa economia.

Com este esforço, Portugal cumpriu, já em 2010, na generalidade dos programas operacionais, as metas que a União Europeia fixou para o final de 2011, o que desmente todos aqueles que, no seu habitual estilo catasfrofista, prognosticavam a perda de fundos comunitários. A verdade é outra: enganaram-se outra vez!

E estes resultados na execução do QREN estão a ter uma tradução bem concreta na nossa economia e na vida dos portugueses. São os mais de

600 centros escolares

que estão concluídos ou em construção. São as mais de

4 000 empresas que estão a ser apoiadas para investir e exportar

. São os mais de

800 mil portugueses abrangidos por acções de formação

, para melhorar as suas competências e qualificações. São as

dezenas de laboratórios e instituições de investigação científica e os mais de 7 500 bolseiros

em acções de formação avançada. São enfim as

81 cidades com iniciativas de regeneração urbana

.

E

também no Proder

[Programa de Desenvolvimento Rural]

melhorámos muito a taxa de execução. O apoio público ao investimento na Agricultura, neste âmbito, atingiu os 580 milhões de euros só em 2010, enquanto que os pagamentos realizados no âmbito do apoio ao rendimento atingiram os 840 milhões de euros. Desta forma, a taxa de execução no Proder Investimento situa-se agora nos 28,1%

.

Senhor Presidente,

Senhoras e senhores Deputados

Quero assinalar, e faço-o com gosto, que a boa execução dos fundos do QREN resultou da resposta e do esforço de todos os agentes – empresas, Administração e autarquias.

Mas foi também o fruto de medidas de resposta directa aos efeitos da crise e de flexibilização da execução dos fundos, como o programa Qualificação-Emprego; a criação das Linhas de Crédito às PME; o aumento selectivo das taxas de co-financiamento; a criação do balcão permanente; o aumento do financiamento dos centros escolares; a simplificação dos procedimentos e a própria aceleração dos pagamentos.

Mas

permitam-me que destaque a dimensão do investimento empresarial. Fruto da recuperação das exportações, temos hoje em curso mais de 4 700 projectos, num investimento elegível de 6 638 milhões de euros

.

Esta semana terminou uma nova fase de concursos, dirigidos exclusivamente às empresas exportadoras, tendo-se registado a maior procura de sempre: 1 091 projectos, para um investimento total de 2 078 milhões de euros, repartidos por projectos de inovação produtiva, de criação de empresas e de acções de promoção internacional, todos eles apresentados por empresas exportadoras. Este é, seguramente, um dos maiores e melhores sinais da resposta das empresas e do nosso sector exportador, aos desafios do País. Uma resposta de mobilização, de esforço. Uma resposta de confiança.

2. Novas metas de ambição para 2011

Senhor Presidente

Senhoras e senhores Deputados

Os resultados alcançados em 2010 e as exigências da nossa economia levaram o Governo a

fixar para 2011 uma meta ainda mais ambiciosa: atingir os 40% de execução global dos fundos do QREN

. Este objectivo corresponde a uma nova aceleração do ritmo de execução dos fundos e ao reforço das opções estratégicas fundamentais do QREN: qualificação dos recursos humanos; inovação e internacionalização da economia; valorização e competitividade do território.

Do mesmo modo,

a meta de execução do Proder Investimento para 2011 foi fixada em 42%

, o que significa mais um forte reforço dos apoios à agricultura portuguesa.

3. Uma agenda para a modernização

Senhor Presidente

Senhoras e senhores Deputados

A aceleração da execução do QREN supõe uma agenda para a competitividade e a modernização da economia portuguesa. E gostaria de vos apresentar aqui algumas das medidas concretas que nos permitirão alcançar o ambicioso objectivo traçado para 2011.

1.º - Reforçaremos em 50%, i.e., em mais 140 milhões de euros, a dotação atribuída aos concursos agora concluídos no âmbito do Sistema de Incentivos para as empresas exportadoras. Criamos assim condições para o essencial: apoiar mais empresas, mais projectos, no momento mais importante para a nossa economia.

2.º - Reforçaremos a linha de crédito QREN Invest, actualmente fixada em 850 milhões de euros, para apoiar as empresas no financiamento da contrapartida nacional necessária à execução dos projectos;

3.º - Aumentaremos para 75% o limite máximo da taxa de apoio ao investimento elegível das empresas

,

tendo em vista obviar às dificuldades de acesso ao financiamento bancário;

4.º - Abriremos, em 2011, novos concursos no âmbito dos Sistemas de Incentivos, com um orçamento previsto de 780 milhões de euros, dos quais se estima que cerca de 560 milhões de euros sejam absorvidos por empresas exportadoras;

5.º - Lançaremos também, em 2011, concursos especificamente dirigidos a sectores inovadores, como é o caso da mobilidade eléctrica;

6.º - Vamos assegurar, já neste 1.º trimestre de 2011, a disponibilização do Empréstimo Quadro do BEI, no valor de 1 500 milhões de euros, destinado a apoiar a contrapartida pública nacional dos projectos QREN;

7. º - Finalmente, renovaremos e reforçaremos os estímulos ao investimento autárquico, em três áreas essenciais: centros escolares, águas e saneamento, e regeneração urbana.

4. Uma tarefa nacional

Senhor Presidente,

Senhoras e senhores Deputados

Este é um momento em que se exige o melhor de nós próprios para fazer face a uma conjuntura difícil que a crise internacional criou.

O Governo está determinado a continuar a fazer a sua parte, para vencer as dificuldades. Com coragem, com trabalho e com ambição. É assim que se defende o País. Esta é a atitude de quem não desiste, nem vira a cara aos problemas.

Mas sei que podemos contar com os portugueses. Com o seu esforço e com a sua iniciativa. Porque é nos portugueses que pomos a nossa confiança. E é porque confiamos nos portugueses, que confiamos no futuro de Portugal.

column1: CONFERÊNCIA DO INSTITUTO UNIVERSITÁRIO EUROPEU «O ESTADO DA UNIÃO» - 8 MAIO 2015
column6: Prime Minister's Speech at the European University Institute, "The State of the Union '' Towards a European architecture we can trust" Florence, May 8, 2015 Ladies and Gentlemen, Seventy years ago ended a terrible war in Europe . Decades of divisions and hatreds have led to a humanitarian disaster that should never be forgotten. The lessons were quickly learned. It was on the ruins of a devastated continent that the European people began to walk the path of peace and unity. In order to live together in peace and prosperity, the Europeans decided to build a common house. Gradually, almost all European democracies joined the project. Not all Europeans who dreamed to be partners in this great project were able to do as they were - either the East or the South - under the yoke of dictatorships. But then, in the seventies, it started a great wave of democratization. First, my own country has finally become a true democracy; Greece and Spain followed quickly. After that, the Berlin Wall fell and Europe returned to be united in a common home of freedom and democracy. It was this great hope and unity environment we decided to create the euro. This was a major milestone in our determination to remain united. This was the path we follow. Then came the crisis. This brought a lot of economic and social pain, particularly in countries like mine, where little work had been done towards a more competitive and fair society and the need for adjustment was greatest. But the crisis has also put to the test our determination to remain united and share a common destiny. It was under great pressure that we put in place a series of measures and emergency devices to respond to the crisis, and a painful learning process began. We do not respond as quickly as we should have done; not we have avoided the frustration or the high costs of uncertainty. Do not we have avoided the recriminations and misunderstandings. But in the end we were able to put the crisis behind us. However, this is not the time for complacency. On the contrary. This is the time to move forward with determination and a common vision. It is time to make choices. I refer to lasting and viable choices. So far we have been living under a structure based on rules. We must move to adopt a framework centered institutions. Now it's time to learn all the hard lessons, face our challenges and restore the euro area with stronger foundations. I propose, then, now let us enter without delay in a second phase of the reform of the eurozone. We must therefore revisit our founding principles. We have to look again at the common purpose that made the European project one object of admiration throughout the world. In my view, at the heart of our project lies the ideal convergence between our peoples: the convergence in prosperity and convergence in freedom. This is what unites us all. We can not afford to lose sight of this ultimate purpose. As advocate equality of opportunity in our national societies, we must also claim equal opportunities for all European people can grow and prosper. This is what should lead the next phase of European reform. If we fail, then we will see growing forces of division and conflict. We will see the disappointment and frustration. In the end, many will start to wonder if it will be better outside Europe rather than within. The rise of populism, extremism, of anti-European political movements, must be taken as a warning of the risks of political fragmentation in the European Union. Should we ignore the frustration and lack of confidence in the future that has been shared by many across Europe? I do not think we should do. A reform of the euro zone-oriented architecture for the future is therefore crucial to address these challenges successfully. We need clear rules and functioning institutions. And we need making processes predictable decision, responsible and timely. For the preparation of the European Council in June, I will send a document with my reform proposals to the President of the European Commission, the President of the European Council and the President of the European Central Bank. Now let me summarize the reforms that advocate for a discussion at European level. The second phase of the European reform I propose revolves around a smarter and deeper integration in key areas. Reflects the undeniable specificity of the euro area in the broader context of the European Union. Promoting balanced prosperity in a monetary union in which a single monetary policy applies to countries with widely divergent growth paths, and coexisting with national fiscal sovereignty, requires specific reforms of the eurozone. However, given the close relationship between the creation of the euro and the deepening of the single market, these proposals should be seen by all Member States, both inside and outside the euro area, as an opportunity and a call to shared responsibility. - First, we need a more coherent framework for structural policies. This involves re-orientation and simplification of the European Semester. We must make the European Semester more operational and effective. In particular, it proposes cimeiros indicators. And should make every country specific recommendations more focused on a limited number of policy priorities and more focused on policies with positive repercussions for all Member States. The implementation of the recommendations should be supported by a much higher level of political commitment, thus ensuring a much faster process and a more immediate impact on national political choices. In parallel, there would be a big improvement if the European Semester reflect specific recommendations and the euro area - in a word, it resulted in an European Recommendation. Also, we have to take a deeper look at the tax coordination. We know that tax coordination is required to avoid negative consequences of poor national decisions. But in the same sense, we must conclude that tax coordination is also necessary to promote positive repercussions. However, genuine fiscal coordination implies that we must take into account not only the fiscal framework of each country, but also the overall fiscal stance of the Union, and in particular the euro area. Let me stress that this objective of a joint position for fiscal policy does not require a budgetary union. It is mainly facing the determination of the Union's budget situation as a whole - and what can reasonably be accomplished through national budgets. However, without taking all the budgetary situation into account, one may come across appropriate national budgetary positions, but with an inappropriate overall tax position. This is an example of how the whole can be different from the aggregate sum of its parts. And points for further discussion on the issue of flexibility and resilience in fiscal policy - ie guidance on the position of the European Union's overall fiscal policy and the euro zone in particular. - Second, we have to create a Financial Union for the growth and stability. Since 2012 I have been advocating a complete Banking Union without which, it seems to me, the monetary union might be destroyed by a financial fragmentation. Since then, we have taken important steps towards a banking union in Europe. But I must insist that we do not have a complete Banking Union, which can give us more stability, more growth, less bank bailouts, and less perverse reactions between sovereign states and the financial sector. A truly integrated European banking system is the only way to increase confidence in the Euro, regardless of individual political decisions. For this we must urgently move forward with a common system of guarantee deposits and financial support co-financed that supports both the guarantee of deposits as the only common fund resolution. But the Financial Union is more than that. Our financial markets need to be extended and deepened with instruments that allow investors to invest funds in Europe, in securities issued by financial institutions and European nãofinanceiras. The goal is to give European businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, access to forms of different and cheaper financing in order to increase investment and create more jobs. The increase in scale, and the availability of new instruments, would be a major step forward in creating a level playing field for European companies, regardless of their geographical location. For this we have to make visible progress in the Capital Markets Union. - Thirdly, and this is my main point, to promote convergence we need a budgetary and institutional framework in which we can trust. We need a European Monetary Fund. In my opinion, this new institution will be central to an architecture of the reformed-oriented euro area for the future. It is a necessity dictated by common sense and by an economic and political sense. If we really want to coordinate economic and monetary policy, then the currency of the eurozone arm should find a real counterpart on the economic side. Otherwise, we will create a new imbalance within the monetary union. In other words, currently the action of the monetary arm is not matched by equivalent and coordinated action from the economic arm. This undermines the positive effects expected from both. This is a serious gap in our institutional concert and we have to face soon. The European Monetary Fund is the way to do it. Let me start by saying very clearly that the European Monetary Fund, as I conceive, does not introduce univocal and permanent transfers between countries. Or remove the need for budgetary discipline at national level. There can be no doubt about any of these issues. Instead, the background would be a shared responsibility instrument, higher reliability and economic soundness. In my opinion, the IMF should have three main functions. Our experience in the last five years tells us that we need a permanent financial adjustment mechanism to provide technical and financial support to Member States facing unsustainable situations. This mechanism should be more independent of national governments in terms of decision-making. And it must be endowed with the technical and financial capacity to act quickly and in an informed manner. Also, it allows a single institution to supervise and monitor the progress of adjustment programs, which means that the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund would be exempt from the mission that had so far. This would represent a maturing of the European approach to crises, such as those we had in the past. And it would take the European Central Bank the uncomfortable position and legally challenged monitoring institution to this kind of national assistance programs. In practice, the creation of the Fund requires the integration of the European Stability Mechanism. But the European Monetary Fund goes beyond that. FME should be provided with sufficient financial capacity to fund national structural reforms with positive repercussions for the euro area as a whole, as well as investment projects focused on modernizing the infrastructure on which the single market depends. With this vocation of investment, and working with the European Investment Bank, the FME would be an important institution to promote domestic rebalancing in the euro area and thus to a more balanced macroeconomic position. Finally, and in the long run, FME also have to perform limited functions of shock absorption, in order to improve the resilience of the euro area as a whole, avoid contagion throughout the EU and reduce the economic and social costs associated with adjustments. Everyone agrees that the eurozone lacks a smart and permanent economic mechanism plays a stabilizing role in responding to specific shocks or asymmetric effects of common shocks. While some of these shocks result of bad national policies, others do not. The shock-absorbing function allow some form of risk sharing to help reduce adjustment costs for the affected countries, limit the need for financial aid and avoid gaps in social cohesion. This function could take the general form of a type of insurance mechanism between the countries of the euro zone and would require a greater degree of harmonization of economic policies and institutions of the participating Member States. The most obvious example of such a function would be a European complement or partially substitute the national unemployment allowance, or even partial Europeanization of active policies in the labor market. Thus, the deepening of economic and monetary union will require some kind of fiscal capacity. This need became obvious during the crisis. The limited fiscal capacity of the euro area is justified by the fact that eurozone countries have fewer tools to deal with necessary adjustments. But also because they make most adjustments rely solely on real economic convergence mine internal devaluation. It is not acceptable that the reaction to specific shocks in each country, and the legacy that it leaves them, eventually delay the process of convergence for many years or even decades - not to say it can even reverse it permanently. We must bear in mind that a deeper convergence is in the interest of everyone in the euro zone because it decreases immediately considerably the risk of sovereign debt crises and the need for financial assistance. So how can this be financed fiscal capacity? In my opinion, not in the same way as we have been funding European programs so far. I mean, not through the sharing of national financial resources and national transfers to the Community budget. Instead, this budget capacity should be funded by own resources, in accordance, of course, with pre-defined rules and limits. Why should we go for own resources? If we continue to link European funding to national financial resources, we will not be able to overcome the political impasse that had so far. We will continue to make every European intervention in a 'zero sum game'. We will continue to make every financial activity in the euro zone in a form of redistribution of resources from some states to other states. The national approach to resource transfers generates political bitterness between Member States and, ultimately hinders our ability to act effectively. Already said before a monetary union to function well requires a true counterpart of economic policy to be speaker of the ECB. This court decision should be responsible for economic policy in the eurozone. This means it must have sufficient political authority and accountable to all the parties involved. The Eurogroup Presidency is the obvious place where you can put such an authority. But not in its current form. In this context, we would need the President of the Eurogroup to become permanent. To increase the responsibility of this instance - the include, among other things, the head of the European Monetary Fund - becomes more difficult to accumulate with the minister of finance functions of a Member State. And most importantly, we can not forget the legitimacy and accountability factor. Thus, several options can be considered. One would be a structure headed by a permanent President of the Eurogroup appointed by the European Council and subject to a hearing by the European Parliament. Another way would be to have a more permanent structure headed by a president of the Eurogroup, appointed by the European Council, but this second option it would be at the same time Vice-President of the European Commission. And it would also be subject to a hearing by the European Parliament. Other options may be considered, but, whatever the option, it must be suitable for the purpose of improving the coordination of economic and fiscal policies, increasing consistency in the monitoring of national and reform program budgets, along with the deepening of the legitimacy of office. And all this could be done within the framework of the existing treaties. My ladies and gentlemen, I am fully aware that the proposals do now are quite ambitious. But are feasible and can be the subject of a new European consensus. Of course, they can be improved, but solve real problems and needs that we can not afford to ignore. It is my deep conviction that we have an opportunity to act decisively now before it is too late. It is in moments of economic recovery that we should reform the institutional structure of the euro area and bring it the aspirations of our citizens. And I do not mean only Portuguese citizens or citizens of southern Europe. I refer to men and women across Europe who look to the future with the legitimate expectation that we should never go through the same trials again. The risks of financial and economic disintegration, social collapse and political fragmentation are all real. We should not be waiting for another emergency in reach to deal with them. I tell you this as the Prime Minister of Portugal, a country that in the last four years has been a credible and reliable European partner. With great sacrifices, Portugal has won this credibility. We knew that new political walls between North and South, or between West and East, would be harmful for Europe. We played our role in building bridges where the political and social forces could be separate European countries. We did it with words and actions, both at home and at European level. Since 2011 we have been living fully within the principle of national responsibility. And since then we have been fighting at European level for this reform agenda in the name of shared responsibility. It is time for these two forms of control are concrete and meaningful way. But I must emphasize that, at the end of the day, the success of the European project will always depend on the assumption of national responsibility: responsibility on respect for common rules and responsibility to keep our own house tidy. If we lose sight of this, any reform proposal, no institutional improvement will be able to give more strength to our Union. This is not a call for solidarity. It is a call to shared responsibility. It is a call to the determination and wisdom to face the challenges that affect us all, without exception. I say this because I really believe that people in Europe understand that we must remain united. Not at any price, of course, but living in an ordinary house whose architecture can all trust. This function could take the general form of a type of insurance mechanism between the countries of the euro zone and would require a greater degree of harmonization of economic policies and institutions of the participating Member States. The most obvious example of such a function would be a European complement or partially substitute the national unemployment allowance, or even partial Europeanization of active policies in the labor market. Thus, the deepening of economic and monetary union will require some kind of fiscal capacity. This need became obvious during the crisis. The limited fiscal capacity of the euro area is justified by the fact that eurozone countries have fewer tools to deal with necessary adjustments. But also because they make most adjustments rely solely on real economic convergence mine internal devaluation. It is not acceptable that the reaction to specific shocks in each country, and the legacy that it leaves them, eventually delay the process of convergence for many years or even decades - not to say it can even reverse it permanently. We must bear in mind that a deeper convergence is in the interest of everyone in the euro zone because it decreases immediately considerably the risk of sovereign debt crises and the need for financial assistance. So how can this be financed fiscal capacity? In my opinion, not in the same way as we have been funding European programs so far. I mean, not through the sharing of national financial resources and national transfers to the Community budget. Instead, this budget capacity should be funded by own resources, in accordance, of course, with pre-defined rules and limits. Why should we go for own resources? If we continue to link European funding to national financial resources, we will not be able to overcome the political impasse that had so far. We will continue to make every European intervention in a 'zero sum game'. We will continue to make every financial activity in the euro zone in a form of redistribution of resources from some states to other states. The national approach to resource transfers generates political bitterness between Member States and, ultimately hinders our ability to act effectively. Already said before a monetary union to function well requires a true counterpart of economic policy to be speaker of the ECB. This court decision should be responsible for economic policy in the eurozone. This means it must have sufficient political authority and accountable to all the parties involved. The Eurogroup Presidency is the obvious place where you can put such an authority. But not in its current form. In this context, we would need the President of the Eurogroup to become permanent. To increase the responsibility of this instance - the include, among other things, the head of the European Monetary Fund - becomes more difficult to accumulate with the minister of finance functions of a Member State. And most importantly, we can not forget the legitimacy and accountability factor. Thus, several options can be considered. One would be a structure headed by a permanent President of the Eurogroup appointed by the European Council and subject to a hearing by the European Parliament. Another way would be to have a more permanent structure headed by a president of the Eurogroup, appointed by the European Council, but this second option it would be at the same time Vice-President of the European Commission. And it would also be subject to a hearing by the European Parliament. Other options may be considered, but, whatever the option, it must be suitable for the purpose of improving the coordination of economic and fiscal policies, increasing consistency in the monitoring of national and reform program budgets, along with the deepening of the legitimacy of office. And all this could be done within the framework of the existing treaties. My ladies and gentlemen, I am fully aware that the proposals do now are quite ambitious. But are feasible and can be the subject of a new European consensus. Of course, they can be improved, but solve real problems and needs that we can not afford to ignore. It is my deep conviction that we have an opportunity to act decisively now before it is too late. It is in moments of economic recovery that we should reform the institutional structure of the euro area and bring it the aspirations of our citizens. And I do not mean only Portuguese citizens or citizens of southern Europe. I refer to men and women across Europe who look to the future with the legitimate expectation that we should never go through the same trials again. The risks of financial and economic disintegration, social collapse and political fragmentation are all real. We should not be waiting for another emergency in reach to deal with them. I tell you this as the Prime Minister of Portugal, a country that in the last four years has been a credible and reliable European partner. With great sacrifices, Portugal has won this credibility. We knew that new political walls between North and South, or between West and East, would be harmful for Europe. We played our role in building bridges where the political and social forces could be separate European countries. We did it with words and actions, both at home and at European level. Since 2011 we have been living fully within the principle of national responsibility. And since then we have been fighting at European level for this reform agenda in the name of shared responsibility. It is time for these two forms of control are concrete and meaningful way. But I must emphasize that, at the end of the day, the success of the European project will always depend on the assumption of national responsibility: responsibility on respect for common rules and responsibility to keep our own house tidy. If we lose sight of this, any reform proposal, no institutional improvement will be able to give more strength to our Union. This is not a call for solidarity. It is a call to shared responsibility. It is a call to the determination and wisdom to face the challenges that affect us all, without exception. I say this because I really believe that people in Europe understand that we must remain united. Not at any price, of course, but living in an ordinary house whose architecture can all trust. Thank you very much. not only the fiscal framework of each country, but also the overall fiscal stance of the Union, and in particular the euro area. Let me stress that this objective of a joint position for fiscal policy does not require a budgetary union. It is mainly facing the determination of the Union's budget situation as a whole - and what can reasonably be accomplished through national budgets. However, without taking all the budgetary situation into account, one may come across appropriate national budgetary positions, but with an inappropriate overall tax position. This is an example of how the whole can be different from the aggregate sum of its parts. And points for further discussion on the issue of flexibility and resilience in fiscal policy - ie guidance on the position of the European Union's overall fiscal policy and the euro zone in particular. - Second, we have to create a Financial Union for the growth and stability. Since 2012 I have been advocating a complete Banking Union without which, it seems to me, the monetary union might be destroyed by a financial fragmentation. Since then, we have taken important steps towards a banking union in Europe. But I must insist that we do not have a complete Banking Union, which can give us more stability, more growth, less bank bailouts, and less perverse reactions between sovereign states and the financial sector. A truly integrated European banking system is the only way to increase confidence in the Euro, regardless of individual political decisions. For this we must urgently move forward with a common system of guarantee deposits and financial support co-financed that supports both the guarantee of deposits as the only common fund resolution. But the Financial Union is more than that. Our financial markets need to be extended and deepened with instruments that allow investors to invest funds in Europe, in securities issued by financial institutions and European nãofinanceiras. The goal is to give European businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, access to forms of different and cheaper financing in order to increase investment and create more jobs. The increase in scale, and the availability of new instruments, would be a major step forward in creating a level playing field for European companies, regardless of their geographical location. For this we have to make visible progress in the Capital Markets Union. - Thirdly, and this is my main point, to promote convergence we need a budgetary and institutional framework in which we can trust. We need a European Monetary Fund. In my opinion, this new institution will be central to an architecture of the reformed-oriented euro area for the future. It is a necessity dictated by common sense and by an economic and political sense. If we really want to coordinate economic and monetary policy, then the currency of the eurozone arm should find a real counterpart on the economic side. Otherwise, we will create a new imbalance within the monetary union. In other words, currently the action of the monetary arm is not matched by equivalent and coordinated action from the economic arm. This undermines the positive effects expected from both. This is a serious gap in our institutional concert and we have to face soon. The European Monetary Fund is the way to do it. Let me start by saying very clearly that the European Monetary Fund, as I conceive, does not introduce univocal and permanent transfers between countries. Or remove the need for budgetary discipline at national level. There can be no doubt about any of these issues. Instead, the background would be a shared responsibility instrument, higher reliability and economic soundness. In my opinion, the IMF should have three main functions. Our experience in the last five years tells us that we need a permanent financial adjustment mechanism to provide technical and financial support to Member States facing unsustainable situations. This mechanism should be more independent of national governments in terms of decision-making. And it must be endowed with the technical and financial capacity to act quickly and in an informed manner. Also, it allows a single institution to supervise and monitor the progress of adjustment programs, which means that the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund would be exempt from the mission that had so far. This would represent a maturing of the European approach to crises, such as those we had in the past. And it would take the European Central Bank the uncomfortable position and legally challenged monitoring institution to this kind of national assistance programs. In practice, the creation of the Fund requires the integration of the European Stability Mechanism. But the European Monetary Fund goes beyond that. FME should be provided with sufficient financial capacity to fund national structural reforms with positive repercussions for the euro area as a whole, as well as investment projects focused on modernizing the infrastructure on which the single market depends.
