column1: VISITA À MARINHA DE GUERRA, BASE DO ALFEITE, ALMADA, 14 MAIO 2012
column6: Speech of the Prime Minister on visit to Navy Alfeite Base War, Almada, 14-05-2012 It is with great pleasure that in my duties as Prime Minister, visiting for the first time the Navy of Portugal. My visit takes place at a time when, in response to an unexpected situation, the military in general and the Navy in particular, demonstrated an excellent responsiveness, putting at sea and by moving to an area of ​​remote operations, a significant number of resources and people. With this visit to the Navy I finish my first cycle of visits to the Portuguese Armed Forces. It was a series of visits of the utmost importance because they enabled me to make contact with important areas of their missions and meet some of the most modern materials and equipment. But also served the Prime Minister, the Government and the country as a whole, to confirm the excellence of the work produced by women and men who serve the state and the nation in its armed forces. They served to confirm that the hard times that the country is going through has been, in the military, and in particular the Navy, lived with high sense of duty, professionalism and honor, values ​​that guide the military institutions. I therefore want to leave here and express my public recognition. Ladies and gentlemen, The Navy is emblematically linked to our collective historical identity. We are a people of the sea. There is much for us the sea is not the border of our country, but its extension. That's what's closely inscribed in our artistic expression, our customs and our history. Many years ago, and over all the risks and all the fears, we respond to the call of the sea and, in doing so, we open the sea for all peoples of the world. It is a fact that we should remember and that we should be proud. Today, the sea continues to call us and our Navy is the first to respond, aware of their responsibilities and the magnitude of the challenges. At sea draws up a horizon of increasingly wider possibilities. This is a common good of the whole country that we have to know how to use and preserve. The sea opens our capabilities in the economy, the sources of energy and minerals, communications, shipbuilding, scientific research, maritime eco-services. It is part of the Government to convert the Sea of ​​overall strategy a key driver of national development, and this priority must be poured into the review of the Strategic Concept of Portugal. It is in order to achieve the objectives of this strategy that will promote the interoperability of multiple Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov .co.uk www.portugal.gov.pt sectors related to maritime activities, with a systemic and integrated approach to the number of areas that have a supportive role and support of their value chains. We want to work in the areas of ports, logistics and maritime transport. We want to encourage the development of fisheries, aquaculture and fish industry, focusing on the formation of a rejuvenated class professionals. We want to promote maritime culture and act in the energy, minerals and biotechnology. We want to invest in the field of Education and Training of activities related to Mar. And it is the sea that plays a very important part of our foreign policy, defense and security. With the extension of the continental shelf, our sea area will be forty times greater than our territory, which expands the potential to explore, but also the security responsibilities that we have to take. It's very wide range of contingencies and threats that we have to deal: maritime accidents, climate change and the rising level of the sea, natural disasters and over-exploitation of ocean resources that challenge our coastal areas, the marine environment and its biodiversity. And of course it includes threats from illegal and criminal activities such as terrorism, piracy, human trafficking and arms trafficking, drug trafficking and illegal fishing. When we account for the goods handled in national ports account for 60 percent of foreign trade, and that is by the sea arriving in the entire oil and 2/3 of the natural gas we consume, we realize that the very economic security of the country depends on the protection of the waterways. But before this, the Navy, in parallel with the performance of its essentially military missions, is called to play an irreplaceable role in the comprehensive and balanced development of our society. Take and operationalize the strategic nature and the consequent prioritization of Sea issues is one of the most important challenges facing us. To this end, it is vital to strengthen the coordination mechanisms between all government departments involved, which should be done in complementarity, overcoming divisions and artificial reserve spaces and little use, to allow us to generate efficiency in operations and achieve economies of scale results. Thus, the government's strategy, the Sea takes four specific dimensions but interconnected: a political dimension, an economic dimension, a cultural dimension and a security dimension. In each, the Navy has a key contribution to make. The Navy is already a key agent of the Portuguese security, defense of national interests and the projection of a dynamic and positive image of the country in the world. In all its present and future tasks, the Navy will benefit from a profitable balance between, on the one hand, the tradition, linked to values ​​and a collective memory; and, on the other hand, modernity, in relief in thinking and application of innovative doctrinal concepts and management methodologies, which become even more efficient procedures and navy operations, at a time Press Street to Star, 4, 1200- 888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt that, as we all know, resources are very scarce. The model of our Navy is founded on balance, optimization and dual use. Today I could here confirm the generalization of these good practices. I do not want to underline the meritorious Doctrine Portuguese Naval, who has signed a School of the utmost importance for the defense of strategic interests of our country, public and academic discussion of the sea potential and the challenges it poses to the scientific equipping of the Navy officers. A doctrine that can be summarized as follows: Steady on Defense, Security and Committed to Partner in Development. Ladies and gentlemen, this crucial moment in the life of the country, we have our Atlantic European partners with us united in the plan to use strategically, an integrated, sustained, this great good that is the sea. We have an integrated view and an increasingly consensus view among us on this priority. I count on your skills, with your talent, with your courage to usher in a new era of open sea and opening to the sea. Thank you very much. Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt

column8:
Discurso do Primeiro-Ministro na visita à Marinha de Guerra
            
Base do Alfeite, Almada, 14-05-2012
            
É com enorme prazer que, nas minhas funções de Primeiro-Ministro, visito pela
            
primeira vez a Marinha de Guerra de Portugal. Esta minha visita ocorre num momento
            
em que, em resposta a uma situação inesperada, as Forças Armadas, em geral, e a
            
Marinha, em particular, demonstraram uma excelente capacidade de resposta, colocando
            
no mar e fazendo deslocar para uma área de operações longínqua, um número muito
            
significativo de meios e de pessoas.
            
Com esta visita à Marinha termino o meu primeiro ciclo de visitas às Forças Armadas
            
Portuguesas. Foi um conjunto de visitas da maior importância pois permitiram-me
            
tomar contacto com áreas importantes das suas missões e conhecer alguns dos seus mais
            
modernos materiais e equipamentos.
            
Mas também serviram ao Primeiro-Ministro, ao Governo, e ao País como um todo, para
            
confirmar a excelência do trabalho produzido pelas mulheres e homens que servem o
            
Estado e a Nação nas suas Forças Armadas. Serviram para confirmar que os tempos
            
difíceis que o País atravessa têm sido, nas Forças Armadas, e em concreto na Marinha,
            
vividos com elevado sentido de dever, de profissionalismo e de honra, valores que
            
norteiam as instituições militares.
            
Quero, portanto, deixar aqui bem expresso o meu reconhecimento público.
            
Minhas senhoras e meus senhores,
            
A Marinha está emblematicamente ligada à nossa identidade histórica colectiva. Somos
            
um povo do mar. Há muito que para nós o mar não é a fronteira da nossa pátria, mas a
            
sua extensão. É isso que está intimamente inscrito na nossa expressão artística, nos
            
nossos costumes e na nossa história. Há muitos anos atrás, e por cima de todos os riscos
            
e de todos os receios, respondemos ao chamamento do mar e, ao fazê-lo, abrimos o mar
            
para todos os povos do mundo. É um feito que devemos recordar e de que nos devemos
            
orgulhar.
            
Hoje, o mar continua a chamar-nos e a nossa Marinha é a primeira a responder,
            
consciente das suas responsabilidades e da grandeza dos desafios. No mar desenha-se
            
um horizonte de possibilidades cada vez mais alargado. Trata-se de um bem comum de
            
todo o País que temos de saber usar e preservar.
            
O mar abre as nossas capacidades na economia, nas fontes de energia e de minerais, nas
            
comunicações, na construção naval, na investigação científica, nos eco-serviços
            
marítimos. Faz parte da estratégia geral do Governo converter o Mar num vector
            
essencial do desenvolvimento nacional, e esta prioridade tem de estar vertida na
            
reapreciação do Conceito Estratégico de Portugal. É com vista a concretizar os
            
objectivos dessa estratégia que iremos promover a interoperabilidade dos múltiplos
            
Rua da Imprensa à Estrela, 4, 1200-888 Lisboa, PORTUGAL
            
TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt
            

sectores ligados às atividades marítimas, com uma abordagem sistémica e integrada,
            
para o conjunto de áreas que têm um papel de suporte e de sustentação das cadeias de
            
valor respectivas.
            
Queremos atuar nos sectores dos portos, da logística e dos transportes marítimos.
            
Queremos incentivar o desenvolvimento das pescas, da aquicultura e da indústria do
            
pescado, apostando na formação de uma classe rejuvenescida de profissionais.
            
Queremos divulgar a cultura marítima e atuar nos sectores da energia, dos minerais e da
            
biotecnologia. Queremos investir no domínio do Ensino e da Formação das atividades
            
ligadas ao Mar.
            
E é no mar que se joga uma parte muito importante da nossa política externa, de defesa
            
e de segurança. Com a extensão da plataforma continental, a nossa área marítima
            
passará a ser quarenta vezes superior ao nosso território, o que expande o potencial a
            
explorar, mas também as responsabilidades de proteção que temos de assumir.
            
É muito amplo o leque de contingências e de ameaças com que temos de lidar: os
            
acidentes marítimos, as mudanças climáticas e a subida do nível das águas do mar, as
            
catástrofes naturais e a exploração excessiva dos recursos do oceano que põem em
            
causa as nossas zonas costeiras, o ambiente marinho e a sua biodiversidade. E inclui
            
evidentemente as ameaças provenientes de atividades ilícitas e criminosas, como o
            
terrorismo, a pirataria, o tráfico de seres humanos e de armas, o narcotráfico e a pesca
            
ilegal. Quando contabilizamos que as mercadorias movimentadas nos portos nacionais
            
representam 60 por cento do comércio externo, e que é pelo mar que nos chega a
            
totalidade do petróleo e 2/3 do gás natural que consumimos, percebemos que a própria
            
segurança económica do País depende da proteção das vias marítimas.
            
Ora, perante isto, a Marinha de Guerra, em paralelo com o desempenho das suas
            
missões de natureza essencialmente militar, é chamada a desempenhar um papel
            
insubstituível no desenvolvimento integral e equilibrado da nossa sociedade.
            
Assumir e operacionalizar o carácter estratégico e a consequente prioridade atribuída às
            
questões do Mar é um dos mais importantes desafios que se nos colocam. Para tal,
            
torna-se vital reforçar os mecanismos de coordenação entre todos os departamentos do
            
Estado envolvidos, o que se deve fazer em complementaridade, superando divisões e
            
espaços de reserva artificiais e pouco úteis, para nos permitir gerar eficácia na atuação e
            
obter economias de escala nos resultados.
            
Assim, na estratégia do Governo, o Mar assume quatro dimensões específicas mas
            
interligadas: uma dimensão política, uma dimensão económica, uma dimensão cultural
            
e uma dimensão de segurança. Em cada uma delas, a Marinha tem um contributo
            
decisivo a dar. A Marinha é já um agente fundamental da segurança dos Portugueses, da
            
defesa dos interesses nacionais e na projeção de uma imagem dinâmica e positiva do
            
País no mundo. Em todas as suas tarefas presentes e futuras, a Marinha beneficiará de
            
uma conciliação proveitosa entre, por um lado, a tradição, ligada aos valores e a uma
            
memória coletiva; e, por outro lado, a modernidade, relevada no pensamento e na
            
aplicação de inovadores conceitos doutrinários e de metodologias de gestão, que
            
tornarão ainda mais eficiente os procedimentos e operações da Marinha, num tempo em
            
Rua da Imprensa à Estrela, 4, 1200-888 Lisboa, PORTUGAL
            
TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt
            

que, como todos sabemos, os recursos são muito escassos. O modelo da nossa Armada
            
está fundado no equilíbrio, na optimização e no duplo uso. Hoje pude aqui confirmar a
            
generalização dessas boas práticas.
            
Também não quero deixar de sublinhar a meritória Doutrina Naval Portuguesa, que tem
            
firmado uma Escola da maior importância para a defesa dos interesses estratégicos do
            
nosso País, da discussão pública e académica sobre as potencialidades do mar e os
            
desafios que coloca, para o apetrechamento científico dos oficiais da Armada. Uma
            
doutrina que pode ser resumida nos seguintes termos: Firme na Defesa, Empenhada na
            
Segurança e Parceira no Desenvolvimento.
            
Minhas senhoras e meus senhores,
            
Neste momento crucial da vida do País, temos os nossos parceiros europeus atlânticos
            
connosco unidos no desígnio de usar estrategicamente, integradamente,
            
sustentadamente, este grande bem que é o mar. Temos uma visão integrada e uma
            
perspectiva cada vez mais consensual entre nós quanto a esta prioridade. Conto com as
            
vossas capacidades, com o vosso talento, com a vossa coragem para inaugurar uma
            
nova era de abertura do mar e de abertura ao mar.
            
Muito obrigado.
            

Rua da Imprensa à Estrela, 4, 1200-888 Lisboa, PORTUGAL
            
TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt

column1: PRÉMIOS EM HOMENAGEM A DIOGO VASCONCELOS - 16 DE MARÇO DE 2012
column6: Speech of the Prime Minister in the delivery of the Porto Commercial Association Awards and the University of Porto in honor of Diogo Vasconcelos March 16, 2012 Let me start by saying that it is with great pleasure that I am in this ceremony, a joint initiative of the Association commercial Port and the University of Porto where they deliver the prizes to the best research projects and new technology-based companies originating at the University. It is an honor and a pleasure to participate in a ceremony where reward ideas and where so well remember that an economy is made up of ideas and collaborative networks that best promote the know and enjoy. Diogo was one of those rare people who look at the world as if it were an ever-new place, a man for whom life was a permanent discovery. I think none of us can truly believe he's not with us, and we can not continue to learn from your findings, your travels and your intelligence, intelligence present in every moment of your life. Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to speak to you of our commitment to structural transformation of the Portuguese economy and, in particular, some ideas that seem to me to be absolutely crucial in this transformation agenda. They may perhaps say that I came to Porto and north of the country to relearn some important things that remain very much alive here, and maybe, maybe a little less live in the city where I work. simple rules and more or less obvious in an old commercial society like ours, including the need to look to international markets as our natural destiny as well as the eigenvalues ​​of the economic activity that the industrial sectors and exporter as well represent and we all should be proud. Our exporters demonstrate every day that are able to compete in the global economy, which truly meet the great opportunities for growth, but where so even have to know rival the best. Competition is a value that we must relearn to appreciate. I like to think it is the economic equivalent of the critical spirit and intellectual world of democracy in the political world. It is the mechanism par excellence of finding ever better solutions, a discovery that necessarily arises from comparing alternatives. Who, like many here, give their best every day to overcome the critical test of market, who succeed in these ambitious projects, deserves the same admiration that the great artists, great creators, big politicians and activists. Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt The difference I think is this: the way we look at the competition. Comparing the law still in force with the law for us and submitted to Parliament already approved in general, they will notice that they differ not so much the nature of certain technical provisions as the way the competition is affirmed. In one case, as a kind of concession to necessity, and on the other, as an affirmation of an ethical and economic value for the new law. That I can promise you: those who work and those who have merit must have a space open to their activity. Which means: without finding the way blocked by unwarranted privilege cores or economic rents that give great benefits to a few in the exact measure in preventing the entry of new players in a given market. Here, we all know, that decides the issue of growth. I have spoken on other occasions of the growth policies adopted in the past as a huge contradiction. On a more superficial level apostávamos on measures to stimulate growth, while a deeper level we were accumulating locks more or less immovable that frustrated any purpose. It was a kind of collective blindness, but also a sign of impatience and nervousness that prevented us from thinking strategically the problem of growth. The correction of external and fiscal imbalances that we are carrying out has costs on growth and employment, but the cause of these costs should of course be sought in accumulated imbalances and not in the adjustment process. I want to stress this point because it seems to me crucial. Not realize what is at stake in this adjustment process is perhaps the greatest danger that threatens us. Consider: if someone is wrong on the way and must return to the starting point, it would be strange to blame the return path for all the time lost. The problem is in the initial error. And in the case of employment, which is for us a priority, can be no doubt that the causes of unemployment growth should be sought in a business environment in many adverse points to the creation of employment, labor law to competition, through slow justice and licensing. The corrections we had to do in our forecasts of the unemployment came further accentuate the very negative diagnosis of the policies pursued in the last decade and the need to advance decisively with our structural transformation agenda of the economy. In other words, and to use simpler language, the transformation of our economic institutions to ensure that they serve the interests of all. The democratization of the Portuguese economy. Such acute crisis as this should be a time when we recover control over our economic destiny. This is the deeper meaning of our adjustment process. This is not a mechanical adjustment. Rather, it is a time when we realize that we, as a political community, have more power than normally judge and that together we can hope to change the institutions and rules that stand in the way to a better society and a more prosperous future . Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt Therefore, it is crucial to the sustainability of our adjustment, as well as the limitation of their immediate costs, it is an opportunity to set our economy for goods and services that can be traded in international markets and therefore can benefit from the high growth power of our times: economic globalization. We all know how important it is to increase our exports, but in fact there are great reasons to invest in tradable goods even when they are not exported, because these goods and services are by nature subject to international competition, with all its benefits. With regard to the results of our adjustment program, I note that the increase in exports has contributed to a rapid and significant adjustment to our external imbalance. The trade balance of goods and services rose from -7.2% of GDP in 2010 to -3.9% in 2011. The current account, in turn, recorded in optical national accounts a 6.5% deficit 2011 a value with an order of magnitude, according to the initially foreseen in the program, would be achieved only in 2012. These are very encouraging results, but the economic internationalization is not only a requirement of the adjustment process of the economy. It is also a huge source of benefits for every company and every entrepreneur. The entry into international markets usually have a high impact on productivity levels of a company. The reasons are many, but among them is access to different markets and exposure to new knowledge, whether they derive from international customers or competitors and suppliers to which a firm is exposed during the process of internationalization. I sincerely hope that our companies understand internationalization as crucial to their survival and growth. This is truly a national objective, as we all have to make, individually and collectively, with greater integration of the Portuguese economy in the global economy. Ladies and Gentlemen, As you know, the issue of financing of the economy and the flow of credit was one of the central themes of the third regular examination to our adjustment program. We have devoted increased attention to this issue because it is absolutely crucial to success in our program that the over-indebtedness of our economy is fixed and decisively corrected at the same time ensure that the deleveraging process is done in a balanced and flexible way not to compromise the economic activity. It is a very delicate process, as will be good to see, but where the two objectives point in the same direction. We have positive signs that our banks are now in a much better situation than at the beginning of the program and, therefore, in a situation where we can expect an improvement in financing conditions for economic activity to monitor closely whether the recovery of growth from next year whether the anticipated effects of structural reforms. As we have repeated, it is important that the Portuguese banking system can answer at the right time and the most appropriate manner. The public debt market also benefits from a gradual improvement in financing conditions, as we have been able to put Rua da Imprensa tickets to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt Treasury market in higher amounts for longer terms and more favorable rates than would be expected for some time. Finally, in the third examination it was agreed to develop initiatives to diversify the sources of funding for our companies, a strategic objective that we can already start working. Ladies and Gentlemen, there is little said that our adjustment process - a technical term - after all has a political sense. It is the time to slowly begin to regain control over our economic destiny. There is therefore a process that happens without our participation and is not a process where we can rest, discourage or disillusion. It all depends on us. There is a new goal to reach every day and little by little these small objectives will form a broader view, which is not only an economic vision, but a vision of a better, more democratic and more just. I would think that everything we do has as main purpose to create a society where ideas like these that distinguish today, and many other ideas that we can not even imagine, have the best conditions to perform. Thank you very much. Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt

column8:
Discurso do Primeiro-Ministro na entrega dos prémios
            
da Associação Comercial do Porto e da Universidade do Porto
            
em homenagem a Diogo Vasconcelos
            
16 de março de 2012
            

Deixem-me começar por dizer que é com muito agrado que estou nesta cerimónia, uma
            
iniciativa conjunta da Associação Comercial do Porto e da Universidade do Porto onde
            
se entregam os prémios aos melhores projetos de investigação e a novas empresas de
            
base tecnológica com origem na Universidade. É uma honra e um prazer participar
            
numa cerimónia onde se premeiam ideias e onde tão bem se recorda que uma economia
            
é feita de ideias e das redes de colaboração que melhor as sabem promover e aproveitar.
            
O Diogo era uma daquelas pessoas raras que olham para o mundo como se ele fosse um
            
lugar sempre novo, um homem para quem a vida era uma descoberta permanente. Julgo
            
que nenhum de nós consegue verdadeiramente acreditar que ele não esteja connosco, e
            
que não possamos continuar a aprender com as suas descobertas, as suas viagens e a sua
            
inteligência, uma inteligência presente em cada momento da sua vida.
            
Minhas Senhoras e Meus Senhores,
            
Gostaria de vos falar da nossa aposta na transformação estrutural da economia
            
portuguesa e, em especial, de algumas ideias que me parece serem absolutamente
            
cruciais nesta agenda de transformação.
            
Poderão talvez dizer que vim ao Porto e ao norte do País para reaprender algumas coisas
            
importantes que permanecem muito vivas por aqui, e talvez, talvez um pouco menos
            
vivas na cidade onde trabalho. Regras simples e mais ou menos óbvias numa velha
            
sociedade comercial como a nossa, entre elas a necessidade de olhar para os mercados
            
internacionais como o nosso destino natural, assim como os valores próprios da
            
atividade económica que os sectores industriais e exportador tão bem representam e de
            
que todos nos devíamos orgulhar.
            
Os nossos exportadores demonstram todos os dias que são capazes de competir na
            
economia global, onde verdadeiramente se encontram as grandes oportunidades de
            
crescimento, mas onde por isso mesmo têm de saber rivalizar com os melhores. A
            
concorrência é um valor que temos de reaprender a apreciar. Gosto de pensar que ela é o
            
equivalente económico do espírito crítico no mundo intelectual e da democracia no
            
mundo político. É o mecanismo por excelência da descoberta de soluções cada vez
            
melhores, uma descoberta que nasce necessariamente da comparação entre alternativas.
            
Quem, como muitos aqui presentes, dá o melhor de si todos os dias para vencer o teste
            
crítico de mercado, quem tem sucesso nestes projetos ambiciosos, merece a mesma
            
admiração que os grandes artistas, os grandes criadores, os grandes políticos e ativistas.
            

Rua da Imprensa à Estrela, 4, 1200-888 Lisboa, PORTUGAL
            
TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt
            

A diferença julgo que é esta: o modo como olhamos a concorrência. Se compararem a
            
lei ainda em vigor com a lei por nós submetida ao Parlamento e já aprovada na
            
generalidade, notarão que elas diferem não tanto no carácter de certas disposições
            
técnicas como no modo como a concorrência é afirmada. Num caso, como uma espécie
            
de cedência à necessidade, e, no outro, como uma afirmação de um valor ético e
            
económico no caso da nova lei.
            
É isso que vos posso prometer: quem trabalha e quem tem mérito deve ter um espaço
            
aberto à sua atividade. O que significa: sem encontrar o caminho obstruído por núcleos
            
de privilégio injustificado ou rendas económicas que conferem grandes benefícios a uns
            
poucos na exata medida em que impedem a entrada de novos agentes num dado
            
mercado.
            
É aqui, todos sabemos, que se decide a questão do crescimento. Falei noutras ocasiões
            
das políticas de crescimento adoptadas no passado como uma enorme contradição. A
            
um nível mais superficial apostávamos em medidas destinadas a estimular o
            
crescimento, ao mesmo tempo que a um nível mais profundo íamos acumulando
            
bloqueios mais ou menos inamovíveis que frustravam qualquer objectivo. Foi uma
            
espécie de cegueira colectiva, mas também um sinal de impaciência e nervosismo que
            
nos impediu de pensar estrategicamente o problema do crescimento.
            
A correção de desequilíbrios externos e orçamentais que estamos a levar a cabo tem
            
custos no crescimento e emprego, mas a causa destes custos deve evidentemente ser
            
procurada nos desequilíbrios acumulados e não no processo de ajustamento. Quero
            
insistir neste ponto porque me parece crucial. Não perceber o que está em causa neste
            
processo de ajustamento é porventura o maior perigo que nos ameaça.
            
Vejamos: se alguém se engana no caminho e tem de regressar ao ponto de partida, seria
            
estranho que culpasse o caminho de regresso por todo o tempo que perdeu. O problema
            
está no erro inicial. E no caso do emprego, que é para nós uma prioridade absoluta, não
            
podem restar dúvidas que as causas do crescimento do desemprego devem ser
            
procurados num ambiente de negócios em tantos pontos adverso à criação de emprego,
            
da lei laboral à concorrência, passando pela lentidão da justiça e do licenciamento. As
            
correções que tivemos de fazer nas nossas previsões da evolução do desemprego vieram
            
acentuar ainda mais o diagnóstico muito negativo das políticas seguidas na última
            
década e a necessidade de avançar decisivamente com a nossa agenda de transformação
            
estrutural da economia. Ou seja, e para usar uma linguagem mais simples, na
            
transformação das nossas instituições económicas para garantir que elas servem os
            
interesses de todos. Na democratização da economia portuguesa.
            
Uma crise tão aguda como esta deve constituir um momento em que recuperamos o
            
controlo sobre o nosso destino económico. É este o sentido mais profundo do nosso
            
processo de ajustamento. Não se trata de um ajustamento mecânico. É antes um
            
momento em que compreendemos que nós, enquanto comunidade política, temos mais
            
poder do que normalmente julgamos e que juntos podemos ter a esperança de mudar as
            
instituições e as regras que se interpõem no caminho para uma sociedade melhor e para
            
um futuro mais próspero.
            

Rua da Imprensa à Estrela, 4, 1200-888 Lisboa, PORTUGAL
            
TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt
            

Por isso mesmo, é crucial para a sustentabilidade do nosso ajustamento, bem como para
            
a limitação dos seus custos mais imediatos, que ele seja uma oportunidade para orientar
            
a nossa economia para bens e serviços capazes de ser transaccionados nos mercados
            
internacionais e que por isso podem beneficiar da grande força de crescimento dos
            
nossos tempos: a globalização económica. Todos sabemos como é importante aumentar
            
as nossas exportações, mas na verdade existem óptimas razões para apostar nos bens
            
transacionáveis mesmo quando eles não são exportados, porque estes bens e serviços
            
estão por natureza sujeitos à concorrência internacional, com todos os seus benefícios.
            
No que diz respeito aos resultados no nosso programa de ajustamento, quero notar que o
            
aumento das exportações contribuiu já para uma rápida e significativa correção do nosso
            
desequilíbrio externo. O saldo da balança de bens e serviços passou de -7,2% do PIB em
            
2010 para -3,9% em 2011. A balança corrente, por sua vez, registou em óptica de contas
            
nacionais um défice de 6,5% em 2011, um valor com uma ordem de grandeza que, de
            
acordo com o inicialmente previsto no programa, seria atingida apenas em 2012.
            
São resultados muito animadores, mas a internacionalização económica não é apenas
            
uma exigência do processo de ajustamento da economia. É também uma enorme fonte
            
de benefícios para cada empresa e para cada empresário. A entrada em mercados
            
internacionais tem normalmente um impacto elevado nos níveis de produtividade de
            
uma empresa. As razões são diversas, mas entre elas está o acesso a mercados diferentes
            
e a exposição a novo conhecimento, quer este provenha dos clientes internacionais quer
            
dos concorrentes e fornecedores a que uma firma é exposta durante o processo de
            
internacionalização. Espero sinceramente que as nossas empresas entendam a
            
internacionalização como crucial para a sua própria sobrevivência e crescimento. Este é
            
verdadeiramente um objectivo nacional, já que todos temos a ganhar, individual e
            
colectivamente, com uma maior integração da economia portuguesa na economia
            
global.
            
Minhas Senhoras e Meus Senhores,
            
Como sabem, a questão do financiamento da economia e do fluxo de crédito foi um dos
            
temas centrais do terceiro exame regular ao nosso programa de ajustamento. Temos
            
dedicado uma atenção redobrada a esta questão porque é absolutamente crucial para o
            
sucesso no nosso programa que o sobre-endividamento da nossa economia seja
            
corrigido e decisivamente corrigido, ao mesmo tempo que asseguramos que o processo
            
de desalavancagem é feito de um modo equilibrado e flexível para não comprometer a
            
atividade económica. É um processo muito delicado, como será bom de ver, mas onde
            
os dois objectivos apontam no mesmo sentido.
            
Temos sinais positivos de que os nossos bancos se encontram hoje numa situação muito
            
mais favorável do que no início do programa e, logo, numa situação onde podemos
            
esperar uma melhoria das condições de financiamento à atividade económica que
            
acompanhe de perto quer a recuperação do crescimento a partir do próximo ano quer os
            
efeitos antecipados das reformas estruturais. Como temos repetido, é importante que o
            
sistema bancário português saiba responder no momento adequado e do modo mais
            
adequado. O mercado de dívida pública beneficia também de uma melhoria progressiva
            
nas condições de financiamento, já que temos sido capazes de colocar Bilhetes de
            
Rua da Imprensa à Estrela, 4, 1200-888 Lisboa, PORTUGAL
            
TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt
            

Tesouro no mercado em montantes mais elevados, por prazos mais longos e a taxas
            
mais favoráveis do que seria de esperar há algum tempo. Finalmente, no terceiro exame
            
foi acordado o desenvolvimento de iniciativas para diversificar as fontes de
            
financiamento das nossas empresas, um objectivo estratégico em que podemos começar
            
já a trabalhar.
            
Minhas Senhoras e Meus Senhores,
            
Disse há pouco que o nosso processo de ajustamento - uma expressão técnica - tem
            
afinal um sentido político. É o momento em que lentamente começamos a recuperar o
            
controlo sobre o nosso destino económico. Não é por isso um processo que aconteça
            
sem a nossa participação e não é um processo em que possamos descansar, desanimar
            
ou desiludir. Tudo depende de nós. Há um objectivo novo a atingir todos os dias e
            
pouco a pouco estes pequenos objectivos formarão uma visão mais ampla, que não é
            
apenas uma visão económica, mas uma visão de uma sociedade melhor, mais
            
democrática e mais justa. Gostaria de pensar que tudo o que estamos a fazer tem como
            
propósito maior criar uma sociedade onde ideias como estas que distinguimos hoje, e
            
muitas outras ideias que não podemos sequer imaginar, tenham as melhores condições
            
de serem realizadas.
            
Muito obrigado.
            

Rua da Imprensa à Estrela, 4, 1200-888 Lisboa, PORTUGAL
            
TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt

column6: Speech of the Prime Minister the course of Auditors of National Defense Lisbon, May 10, 2012 Mr. Director of the Institute of National Defence, ladies and Auditors Course of National Defence, is for me a great pleasure and a great responsibility to speak in the Course Auditors of National Defense. I would like to take this opportunity to introduce you to some of the fundamental principles of government policy. Nothing can replace the clarity of the organizing principles of a policy, especially those defining moments where we are called to operate a transformation in its foundations. It will soon be given possession to a commission for the revision of the current Strategic Concept Defense. This committee, which will be chaired by Professor Luís Fontoura, with the presence and contribution of many experts and personalities of our social life, academic, business, political, diplomatic and military, trying to cover all possible areas of intervention and be adequately representative . In the context of its intervention will count immediately with a dense and important work at the Institute, under the direction of its Director, here present, constituting as general basis for the development of a Security Strategic Concept and National Defence to take this opportunity to extol and thank. Ladies and Gentlemen, we can not forget, when we reflect on principles and strategies, they are intended to be applied in a context of great uncertainty. I think there are reasons more or less contingent that explain this uncertainty, but also more fundamental reasons. Regarding the former, it is impossible not to notice that we cross a time when almost all the traditional factors of uncertainty in the domestic and international security manifest themselves simultaneously. First, we see the rise of new powers in the global system and everyone knows that this has traditionally been a cause of great disturbance in the history of international relations. I think not repeat past mistakes and to know to build together a new global system appropriate to the new reality, but this is undoubtedly a demanding challenge. Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt At the same time, recent years have been marked for democratic transition processes in many cases still incomplete. also were years of financial and economic crisis, which creates tensions and significant risks to the process of globalization. From a certain point of view, we are living in the center of a perfect storm. Up to us to make this moment a desirable transformation opportunity. As I said, I think there are more permanent and more fundamental reasons for the uncertainty or, if you will, the turbulence of the present moment. We do not live in a time of clear separation concepts. It is no longer possible, for example, separating internal security and external security of our priorities should be precisely the development of structures that enable the integrated approach to these issues. The promotion of national interests, the preservation of stability, timely response to crises and threats are cross-cutting objectives that require an integrated approach. The reason being of the state is to protect its citizens and ensure their safety. That is also the first task of the welfare state, it is safety and your security equal to everyone who should get equal opportunities in a free society. Not only is the disappearance of a clear boundary between internal and external security, between security forces and political institutions, which puts us a new challenge. The border between defense policy and economic policy is equally tenuous and even difficult to establish. There can be no doubt that our new strategic concept of national security and defense must be built with special attention to economic factors of a security policy and the links between security and international economic relations. The crisis we are experiencing is the best proof of this thesis. We know that the threats to financial stability and economic growth are also security threats and immediately to our ability to develop an independent and effective security policy. The debt reduction can and should be understood as a way to reduce our dependence on external factors we can not control and thus to organize the basis for sustainable economic growth, less vulnerable to expansion and sudden or violent contractions. At the same time, any traditional political alliances is its economic equivalent at the opening of the Portuguese economy abroad. It is a decisive part of a modern security strategy concern to multiply our economic presence in other regions, shifting the Portuguese economy increasingly to the center of the network connections that constitute the global economy. I do not think that you are to say anything they do not know well. The intelligent use of available resources is not something that the security and defense institutions have to learn from politicians and economists. This is rather the central principle of strategy, so perhaps the politicians and economists who have something to learn from the classics of strategy and defense when they tell us that resources and operational capacity to be concentrated in the most useful use of scenarios and more likely. I do not think so that our needs for fiscal consolidation and structural rationalization should be seen as an external imposition. It is a Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt essential principle of a policy intelligent security rationalization of costs in order to maximize the advantages and benefits that we can get. I would therefore like to emphasize the opportunity for a new European defense policy based on combining and sharing (pooling and sharing) of military capabilities, including through the joint investment of the European Defence Agency. The European institutions have said that the financial crisis and its impact on national defense budgets may ultimately be a golden opportunity to increase European cooperation in the crucial area of ​​development of new military capabilities and support for scientific and technological research in this area. Conducted in an intelligent way, the development of military capabilities can have a very positive impact on the rest of the economy, promoting innovation and investment. It is something that, as Europeans, we can do better together than alone. The scale of the crisis became even more pronounced scarcity of resources that individual states can mobilize to solve their problems and the provision of objects indispensable to their populations. It has therefore even more acute the need for the Member States of the European Union, in countries belonging to NATO, as well as its closest strategic partners, share resources and raise to a new level its institutions and cooperation practices. Unilateral and individual proposals for solution to these problems will have little chance of success. On the contrary, only the concerted efforts, only the sharing of resources, only operational cooperation at European level and to a level that goes beyond European borders, can guarantee the efficiency we need. The achievement of these objectives implies, on the side of the Government, but also of all institutions related to the fields of defense, external relations and the economy, the conduct of an active foreign policy in the service of our political, economic and security. The purposes that guide our foreign policy express our ambition, which can only be performed if the conduct of competent and firmly, but also as teach the old school of diplomacy, with the necessary discretion, with the talent for the reconciliations and with the quiet force of example. An ambitious foreign policy with regard to our role in Europe and relations with our Portuguese-speaking partners and our allies. But would also audacious in promoting our economic diplomacy and in this context, the intensification of our cooperation in Africa, Asia and Latin America. Ladies and gentlemen, In the current circumstances has become even truer to say that the fate of Portugal is closely linked to Europe. In this sense, it accelerated the trend, which accompanies all our democratic history, the intersection of national interest with the collective European interest. We share with our European partners fundamental challenges. And we share with them the commitment to structural reform of the Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal. gov.pt our economies and our institutions to respond positively, not only the threats looming on the near future, but also the opportunities that the world situation offers. We do not want to spend next to these opportunities, or to fail to follow the rest of the world largely finally united in a common effort for the prosperity and freedom of peoples. In the current European crisis we respond with a new Europe. And a new Europe means overcoming endogenous vulnerabilities and gaps in the European institutional framework. European architecture is not closed, as the last few months show. It is a process of continuous deepening taking place in negotiation with all, in line with fundamental consensus, beyond the strict partisan, ideological preferences or national of each of the States. What we have inherited from previous generations of European leaders needs to be completed, or in other words, needs to be attuned to the needs that have become more evident. The crisis we are experiencing has highlighted weaknesses of systemic, institutional and structural, in large European company. urgent has the need to complete Maastricht and Lisbon. This means greater coordination of economic and fiscal policies, greater scrutiny and corrective surveillance for timely signs of imbalances and weaknesses, new regulatory regimes and bank resolution, and deepening the Internal Market. And also means accelerating the reform and economic growth agenda for the Union. Once overcome the policy coordination problems, financial indiscipline and economic integration, we should look forward to a new political integration and reinforcing cycle institutional of our monetary union. One of the steps that have since data to adjust the institutional structure and rules of the European Union to new problems was the signature, and Portugal on ratification of the Treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism and the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Governance in the EU economic and Monetary. Are two treaties that aim to correct and to lay the foundations of a monetary union more robust and stable. But also aim to frame a new era of growth for Europe. These treaties finally define coherent mechanisms of crisis management. Set budget goals of stability and meeting the future financial burden. In this sense, these treaties - and already had occasion to say in Parliament - further driving up the protection of countries like Portugal than other European partners with more mature mechanisms and longer lasting reputations of financial responsibility. Enables assimilation in the institutions and procedures of our democracy the hard lessons of the past, the need to sustain public finances as a necessary means to protect our future and the safeguarding of the welfare state and our way of life. Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt More than that, these Treaties and European initiatives in recent months indicate that politically we have to reconcile the way of solidarity and integration with the responsibility and prevention. Ladies and gentlemen, these basic data of national and European situation naturally follows the priority attribute from the first time to put Portugal at the forefront of European concert. Maintain a permanent activity of dialogue and close cooperation with various European capitals and the EU institutions. Let me emphasize that, in recent months, the government has sought to take this work as far as possible in bilateral relations with Spain, as exemplified in the Luso-Spanish Summit held yesterday in Porto. Portugal is facing a truly key challenge for the future: to be both a model of European integration and a model of openness to the world. Indeed, if our economic and financial integration of space to play ever more intensely in the European context, as our relevance as a country is established and rooted also increasingly in our relationship specific outside Europe, we should deepen with a new sense of urgency and a long-term vision. Hence the importance of economic diplomacy. The main drivers of growth and employment in the current circumstances are known: exports and the attraction of foreign investment. Here priority should be given the extra-European area, for obvious reasons related not only to the economic slowdown in Europe, but with the current and expected global economic cycle. It is precisely in this light that I consider the Lusophone an emerging economic policy framework in the global world we should explore with renewed commitment and long-term vision. We are faced, so to speak, with a possible strategic spring to be exploited. We must look to the CPLP and each of the countries to which it belongs, as our emerging community on a global scale, with more than 250 million citizens who express themselves in Portuguese, united by cultural ties that take on a new importance in a globalized world. A community in which our country has yet pugnado respect for fundamental principles of democracy, the rule-of-law and human rights, engaging in the stabilization and development of the states that are part of it. That is the concern that has mobilized us to the current crisis resolution in Guinea-Bissau. It was therefore not by chance that the first two bilateral visits I made to extra-European area have been precisely to Brazil and Angola, where he addressed the Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt not just a strategic partnership, but a political alliance, economic, business, commercial and cultural. They were also very important the summit that we held with Mozambique and the visit I just make Maputo. Ladies and gentlemen, We are founding members of NATO and active participants in this great partnership for peace and collective security. In the coming years, Portugal must maximize the opportunities created by the adoption in Lisbon, the new strategic concept of NATO. Within two weeks I will be in Chicago for the NATO summit. The featured topics are Afghanistan, the adaptation of our forces, capabilities and defense posture against the new security environment, and the promotion of the Alliance's partnership policy. In Afghanistan, the script ahead of course, having been set at the NATO Summit in Lisbon. It was then that pledge with President Karzai to complete by 2014 the transfer of responsibility for the country's security, which has been guaranteed by ISAF in the last decade. But 2014 will not represent the end of NATO's cooperation with Afghanistan. On the contrary, we reaffirm our continued political commitment to support the Afghan authorities in consolidating peace, democracy and the rule of law. Afghan forces will continue to rely on the support of Alliance countries in the formation and training. The second theme of the Chicago Summit, the defense capabilities, the focus will be on a budget constraint frame, in the search for creative solutions to avoid unnecessary duplication of resources and waste. It is the philosophy of the concepts put forward by NATO and the European Union of Smart Defence and Pooling and Sharing, which constitute the two faces of the same coin, the sharing and pooling capabilities. And we hope that through the practical application of these concepts will contribute to strengthening the partnership between the two organizations. The principles that we defend, the vision that guides us, the sense of our time and the challenges of its own, humility before a future full of risks and uncertainty, these concerns are afinais the same when we discuss our internal policy and when we trace a path to our goals in the international arena. We find here the reason for new optimism. Personally, I find the consistency of this vision proof that we learned achieve a new clarity of purpose. We shall overcome these challenges because we want and we know to win. Thank you very much. Press Street to Star, 4, 1200-888 Lisbon, PORTUGAL TEL + 351 21 392 35 00 FAX + 351 21 392 36 16 EMAIL pm@pm.gov.pt www.portugal.gov.pt
